metadata.title: UK Framework Procurement Agreement (Packaged Foods)
metadata.tariff_adjustment_policy: Section 6: Seller may request price increase if new UK tariffs raise landed cost by >5% vs Baseline Duty; Buyer may reject increases >6% in rolling 12 months and cancel; decreases must be passed through.
metadata.baseline_duty_and_hs_reference: Schedule A lists HS codes and baseline UK duty (0%) for ES-origin foods.

queries.question: UK introduces a 7% tariff on HS 1509.10 (olive oil) where Baseline UK Duty is 0%. For a call-off of 40,000 L at a DDP unit price of £5.60, what price increase can Seller request and can Buyer refuse?

answer.summary: Seller’s landed cost increase is 7% of Customs Value. Section 6.1 permits passing through the incremental duty since >5%. However, Buyer may reject increases exceeding 6% in a rolling 12 months and cancel undelivered orders.
answer.who_bears_tariff: Seller (IOR under DDP) initially; economic pass-through per contract limits.

queries.question: If tariffs drop from 7% back to 0% on HS 1902.19, what happens to pricing?

answer.summary: Any decrease must be passed through to Buyer effective on the implementation date.

queries.question: List HS codes, origin and Baseline UK Duty for all Products.

answer.summary: HS 1902.19 (0%), 2103.20 (0%), 1509.10 (0%), origin ES; Incoterm DDP; IOR Seller.

queries.question: Who is Importer-of-Record and what are the implications for tariff exposure?

answer.summary: Seller is IOR under DDP; Seller pays duties and handles customs. Economic exposure can be passed through only if landed cost increases >5%, and Buyer can cap effective increases at 6% with cancellation option.

queries.question: Assume the UK imposes 4% on HS 2103.20 and 3% on HS 1902.19. Can Seller increase prices under Section 6.1?

answer.summary: No. The landed cost increases (3-4%) are below the >5% threshold; no price increase right under Section 6.1.

queries.question: If Seller proposes an 8% price increase due to tariffs across the portfolio within 12 months, what recourse does Buyer have?

answer.summary: Buyer may reject increases exceeding 6% in a rolling 12-month period and cancel undelivered orders for affected Products.

queries.question: Explain how rules of origin affect duty liability under this Agreement.

answer.summary: Seller must maintain origin documentation to qualify for preferential duty under the EU-UK TCA; if origin changes and duty applies, Seller remains responsible for resulting duties.

queries.question: Summarize tariff exposure profile of this Framework.

answer.summary: DDP/IOR Seller: Seller bears tariff and VAT liability, with limited pass-through if >5%. Buyer can cap increases at 6% and cancel; decreases must be passed through.
